subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quikscript extensions to Shavian (or separate script)

messageBody:
On Apr 20, 2013, at 12:45 AM, Michael Everson <everson@...> wrote:

> On 20 Apr 2013, at 01:20, Jean-François Colson <jf@...> wrote:
>
>> With a consistent use of variation selectors, a single font could handle
>> both scripts, even if they were unified.
>
> Perhaps. But if there had to be that much markup (if and only if OpenType failed) then I would argue for disunification.

I'm writing a Web page in a text editor that has both Shavian and Quikscript in it. My own ability to read Shavian is limited, and I'm using a character picker to insert Shavian characters (much like I would with Greek).

Now suppose I'm using a font that supports the unified QS-and-Shavian parts. What would I/the foundry need to do in order for "fourth" to look Shavian-y in the Shavian parts and Quikscripty in the Quikscript parts of my document? 𐑓𐑹𐑔 looks fine to Shavianists, but AFAICT each of these three characters would need a variation selector in order to look right to me — otherwise it looks like a sequence of:

- an unvoiced character that looks like a too-tall .At
- an R-controlled vowel of uncertain pronunciation
- [f] (it should be pronounced [T])

Because of this, I'd probably end up putting VSs after letters for:

- p
- b
- t
-
-
- g
- θ
- ð
- f
- v
-
-
- ʃ
- ʒ
-
-
- j
-
- (h pre-disunified)
- (ʍ not in Shavian)
-
- (m pre-disunified)
- (n pre-disunified)
- (l pre-disunified)
-
-
- i
-
- eɪ
-
- aɪ
- ɑ
- ɔ
-
- ɔɪ
-
- aʊ
-
- ʊ
- u

- (ks not in Shavian)
- (gz not in Shavian)
- (ɬ not in Shavian)
- (x not in Shavian)

Blank lines are placeholders for sufficiently-similar letters. With the current proposal, 45% (20/44) of the alphabet would require VSs to look right to a Quikscript reader, including Excite, Exam, Llan, and Loch.

In a similar vein, 66% (29/44) of the alphabet would need some sort of modification (either a VS or a previously proposed Quikscript extension) to be readable to a Quikscript reader. If nearly two thirds of the alphabet needs some sort of modification to be readable in Quikscript, what's the advantage of having the two scripts be unified at all?
